conclusion: The problem involves a small slider starting from rest at point P on an inclined track AB, undergoing an elastic collision with a ball on a horizontal track BC, and the ball subsequently passing through a pipe and a semi-circular track before landing at point Q.
The goal is to calculate the maximum horizontal distance x_max between the landing point Q and point F, given that the ball just barely passes the highest point E.

The setup includes a horizontal platform of height H=0.4m, an inclined rough track AB with angle θ=37°, a horizontal smooth track BC, a quarter-circular smooth pipe CD with radius r=0.1m, and a semi-circular smooth track DEF with radius R=0.2m.
The centers of the pipe CD and track DEF are at points O1 and O2, respectively, and points O1, D, O2, and F are on the same horizontal line.
The triangular prism G is fixed on a rod directly below point F, and the ball lands at point Q on the ground.
The coefficient of kinetic friction between the slider and the track AB is μ=1/12, and trigonometric values are given as sin37°=0.6 and cos37°=0.8.
The frictional force acting on the slider on the inclined track AB is calculated as μ * mg = (1/12) * 9.8 = 0.39 N.
The gravitational force acting on the slider is mg = 9.8 N.
The net force acting on the slider is F_net = mg - μ * mg = (1 - 1/12) * mg = (11/12) * mg.
The acceleration of the slider is a = F_net / m = (11/12) * g.
The velocity of the slider after sliding down the inclined track is v = a * t = (11/12) * g * t.
The distance traveled by the slider on the inclined track is s = (1/2) * v * t = (11/24) * g * t^2.
The ball passes through the pipe CD with a radius of r=0.1m.
The frictional force acting on the ball in the pipe is μ * mg = (1/12) * 9.8 * 0.1 = 0.085 N.
The net force acting on the ball in the pipe is F_net = mg - μ * mg = (1 - 1/12) * mg = (11/12) * mg.
The acceleration of the ball in the pipe is a = F_net / m = (11/12) * g.
